Award.AwardTitle: Chemoenzymatic methods for automated carbohydrate synthesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Synthesis (SYN) Program in the Division of Chemistry supports the work of Professor Xi Chen of the University of California-Davis on developing efficient chemoenzymatic methods which can be readily adapted for automated synthesis of complex carbohydrates. Multistep one-pot-multienzyme processes are designed to synthesize tagged complex carbohydrates from simple mono- or disaccharides. The method allows efficient solution-phase synthesis complemented with facile column purification. The adaption of the proposed method to automated synthesis of carbohydrate will allow easy access to major naturally occurring mammalian carbohydrates even by non-specialists.

The proposed research involves multi-disciplinary cutting-edge research in the fields of organic chemistry, biochemistry, and molecular biology, providing excellent training opportunity for graduate students, undergraduate students, and summer high school students. The new method proposed here will allow the efficient product of complex carbohydrates which are important molecules in biological systems. The products obtained will lead to a better understanding of their functions.

Carbohydrates displayed on the surface of mammalian cells play essential roles on how the cells are able to function normally, communicate with each other, and respond to immune regulations. Chemical synthesis of biologically important complex carbohydrates is a time consuming process involving the use of large amount of organic solvents and numerous chemical reactions. It also requires skilled chemists with extensive training. Enzymatic synthesis with high yield and high selectivities in aqueous solutions under mild physiological conditions provides a preferred alternative approach but still suffers from tedious product purification processes. By introducing a suitable tag to simple carbohydrate substrates, the Chen Research Group has developed efficient chemoenzymatic methods that combine the strengths of highly efficient enzymatic synthesis and simple solid phase extraction method which can be adapted to automated synthesis of carbohydrates. The enzymatic synthesis allows the reactions to be carried out in aqueous solution. Solid phase extraction significantly simplifies the purification process, decreasing the purification time from 12 hours to less than 10 minutes and reducing the amount of organic solvent used significantly. Research outcomes of this project allow the biologically important complex carbohydrates be synthesized in aqueous solution in high yield and be purified with a simple cartridge with ease. It is an environmental friendly approach with minimal use of organic solvent. The method can be adapted to automated synthesis to allow the production of complex carbohydrates by even non-specialists. This work allows easy access of diverse carbohydrates which can be used to elucidate their important biological functions and to develop carbohydrate-based diagnostics and therapeutics. Other than providing excellent interdisciplinary training opportunities to graduate students and undergraduate students in the Chen group at UC-Davis, the project also provides hands-on experience to high school students and undergraduate students from other campuses in the nation and from other countries.
